content.webTitle: Michael Gove: I made mistakes in leadership bid

fields.headline: Michael Gove: I made mistakes in leadership bid
fields.bodyText: Michael Gove and David Cameron have not spoken properly since the EU referendum result on 24 June, the former justice secretary has revealed in a candid interview where he spoke of his regrets about ruined friendships with both Cameron and Boris Johnson. Gove was sacked from the cabinet by the newly elevated Conservative prime minister, Theresa May, after a week which saw him mount his own stalled bid to be Tory leader, having previously pledged his support for Johnson. He was beaten into third place by May and Andrea Leadsom. In a BBC interview with Fern Britton, Gove said he knew the phrase “doing a Gove” had become synonymous with backstabbing, and that May had been right to sack him. He and his wife, the Daily Mail columnist Sarah Vine, had been close to the Camerons but had not had a “proper conversation” since the vote for Brexit, which he had decided to back on a point of principle, he said. “It was better to say to David that I couldn’t support him and to go with my heart than to suppress my feelings on the matter … he thought I would either keep schtum or say, ‘I am going to support the prime minister’.” Gove declined to reveal what Johnson said to him when they spoke after he withdrew his support for the former London mayor’s leadership bid. However, he denied reports that he had not spoken to Johnson’s team before issuing a statement announcing his own bid. On the morning of that announcement, he said: “I wanted to help build a team behind Boris Johnson so that a politician who argued for leaving the European Union could lead us to a better future. But I have come, reluctantly, to the conclusion that Boris cannot provide the leadership or build the team for the task ahead. I have, therefore, decided to put my name forward for the leadership.” Gove told Britton he had “tried to speak to Boris but the phone rang dead when I called him, so I then spoke to his lieutenant in order to explain what we were going to do. So, no, I did definitely did try to ring Boris at the time.” He said he regretted how the announcement came about. “The way in which I declared my stand for the leadership, I shouldn’t have done it in that way. I know that I made mistakes so there’s no point in me complaining. I’ve got to bear the consequences of my own actions.” Gove said in his speech announcing his leadership bid that he did not want to be prime minister. “I did almost everything not be a candidate for the leadership of this party,” he said. “I was so very reluctant because I know my limitations. Whatever charisma is, I don’t have it, whatever glamour may be I don’t think anyone could ever associate me with it.” His own analysis of his flaws proved to be correct, Gove told Britton. “I also think that, my initial instinct, that I was not the best person to put themselves forward as a potential prime minister, well, most of my colleagues agreed.” He added: “When Theresa became prime minister she said that she no longer had a place for me in the cabinet and, to be honest, if I’d been in her shoes I would have sacked me too. So I entirely accept that sacking me at the time was the right thing to do. “I had six years when I was a government minister, I had a chance to make a difference – I hope that I did. But nothing is forever in politics and having had the chance to serve, having had the chance to make a difference, I have to accept that the way in which I spent the final week or so of my ministerial life involved my making mistakes, and having made mistakes, you have to take the consequences.” Gove said he was now focusing on his work on the commons committee on exiting the EU, and wanted to campaign for children at risk of abuse or neglect. “I had a chance to argue for things that I believed in,” he said. “And I will also have the chance, I hope, in the future to be able to argue for other things in which I believe, to make a contribution.” Meanwhile, Cameron, who stepped down as MP for Witney after the referendum result, said at DePauw University in Indiana on Thursday night that the rise of populism “cost me my job”. Europe was “poisoning politics in my own party”, he said, defending his decision to hold the referendum, though he also joked: “I sleep like a baby – I wake up every hour calling for my mother”. The former prime minister said many saw the vote for both Brexit and Donald Trump as a “movement of unhappiness and concern about the state of the world”. “I see more trouble ahead. It is not working as it was intended. Some countries have seen decades of lost growth.”
